verses.text: Early in the morning, the chief priests, with the elders, the scribes, and the whole council, made their plans. They bound Jesus, led him away, and handed him over to Pilate.
verses.comment: The religious leaders’ swift assembly emphasizes the urgency and gravity of their actions. The transfer to Pilate shows that only the Roman authority could order an execution, fulfilling how Jesus would die (see John 18:31-32).

verses.text: Pilate questioned him, 'Are you the King of the Jews?' Jesus answered him, 'You have said so.'
verses.comment: Jesus’ response is reserved, yet affirming. 'You have said so' is an indirect confirmation—highlighting the mystery of his kingship. His kingdom is not political (cf. John 18:36).

verses.text: And the chief priests accused him of many things.
verses.comment: Multiple accusations are brought to make the case for Roman punishment. See Isaiah 53:7 for prophecy of the servant silent before his accusers.

verses.text: Pilate again asked him, 'Do you not answer? See how many things they accuse you of!'
verses.comment: Pilate is surprised by Jesus’ silence—this composure in suffering further fulfills prophecy (Isaiah 53:7).

verses.text: But Jesus gave no answer, so that Pilate was amazed.
verses.comment: Christ’s silence is prophetic—he fulfills the image of the suffering servant, embracing God’s will without resistance.

verses.text: Now at the feast, Pilate used to release one prisoner to them, anyone whom they requested.
verses.comment: This custom, not mentioned outside the Gospels, symbolizes a substitution—one innocent for the guilty (see John 18:39-40).

verses.text: There was a man named Barabbas, imprisoned with the rebels who had committed murder during the uprising.
verses.comment: Barabbas represents a violent revolutionary. The crowd’s preference for him is a powerful contrast to Jesus, who is blameless.

verses.text: The crowd went up and began to ask Pilate to do what he usually did for them.
verses.comment: Public demand shapes the choice before Pilate—a tension between justice and popularity.

verses.text: Pilate answered them, 'Do you want me to release for you the King of the Jews?'
verses.comment: Pilate highlights Jesus’ royal title, while echoing Messianic expectations (see Psalm 2:6).

verses.text: He knew that it was out of envy that the chief priests had handed Jesus over.
verses.comment: Pilate’s insight adds irony—the innocent Christ is condemned not for guilt but for envy.

verses.text: But the chief priests stirred up the crowd, so that he would release Barabbas instead.
verses.comment: Manipulation leads to injustice—the guilty released, and the innocent condemned.

verses.text: Pilate again said to them, 'Then what should I do with the one you call the King of the Jews?'
verses.comment: The critical question shows Pilate’s uncertainty and the crowd’s influence over him.

verses.text: They shouted back, 'Crucify him!'
verses.comment: Crucifixion was the most humiliating Roman punishment, fulfilling Psalm 22 and Isaiah 53:12 as prophecy of the Messiah’s suffering.

verses.text: Pilate said to them, 'Why? What evil has he done?' But they shouted even louder, 'Crucify him!'
verses.comment: Pilate’s attempt at reason is drowned out, reflecting humanity’s blindness to true innocence.

verses.text: So, wanting to satisfy the crowd, Pilate released Barabbas to them. After having Jesus flogged, he handed him over to be crucified.
verses.comment: Flogging was brutal. Jesus, the true innocent, takes the place of the guilty—a profound symbol of substitutionary sacrifice (see Isaiah 53:4-5).

verses.text: The soldiers led him away inside the palace—called the Praetorium—and gathered the whole cohort.
verses.comment: The Praetorium is the Roman governor’s residence in Jerusalem. A cohort could be up to 600 men, underlining the magnitude of the event.

verses.text: They dressed him in a purple robe, and twisted a crown of thorns, and put it on him.
verses.comment: Purple signifies royalty; the crown of thorns is mockery and suffering, echoing Genesis 3:18 and Psalm 22:7.

verses.text: They began to salute him, 'Hail, King of the Jews!'
verses.comment: Their mocking addresses Jesus with the Messianic title, paradoxically acknowledging his kingship as foretold (see Matthew 2:2).

verses.text: They struck his head with a reed, spat on him, and knelt before him in mock homage.
verses.comment: Their cruel parody fulfills prophecy of the suffering Messiah (see Psalm 22; Isaiah 50:6).

verses.text: After they had mocked him, they took off the purple robe and put his own clothes back on him. Then they led him out to crucify him.
verses.comment: Mockery and humiliation precede the cross—Jesus is publicly shamed before his sacrifice.

verses.text: A certain man named Simon of Cyrene, the father of Alexander and Rufus, was passing by, coming in from the countryside, and they compelled him to carry Jesus’ cross.
verses.comment: Cyrene is in Africa; Simon’s sons are mentioned—likely witnesses in the early church (see Romans 16:13). Participation in Christ’s suffering is foundational to faithful discipleship.

verses.text: They brought him to the place called Golgotha, which means 'Place of the Skull.'
verses.comment: Golgotha is a hill outside Jerusalem; the site of execution carries ominous symbolism—death defeated through Christ’s sacrifice.

verses.text: They offered him wine mixed with myrrh, but he did not take it.
verses.comment: Wine with myrrh was a mild sedative to lessen pain; Jesus refuses, choosing full experience of suffering (see Psalm 69:21).

verses.text: Then they crucified him and divided his garments, casting lots for them to decide what each should take.
verses.comment: His garments divided fulfills Psalm 22:18—demonstrating fulfillment of prophecy and the totality of his self-emptying.

verses.text: It was the third hour when they crucified him.
verses.comment: The third hour is about 9 a.m., corresponding with the time for the morning sacrifice in the Temple. Christ, as the true sacrifice, fulfills the ancient rites (see Exodus 29:38-39).

verses.text: The inscription of the charge against him read, 'The King of the Jews.'
verses.comment: The inscription is both accusation and proclamation—Jesus indeed is the true King (cf. 2 Samuel 7:12-16).

verses.text: With him they crucified two criminals, one on his right, and one on his left.
verses.comment: Fulfillment of Isaiah 53:12: 'numbered with the transgressors'. His solidarity with the guilty highlights his redemptive work.

verses.text: And the scripture was fulfilled that says, 'He was counted with the lawless.'
verses.comment: Mark explicitly ties the event to prophecy—Isaiah 53’s suffering servant motif highlights Christ’s saving mission.

verses.text: Those who passed by mocked him, shaking their heads and saying, 'Aha! You who would destroy the Temple and build it in three days,'
verses.comment: Their jeers reference Jesus’ claim to rebuild the Temple, a statement with profound significance—his body is the true Temple (John 2:19-21).

verses.text: 'Save yourself, and come down from the cross!'
verses.comment: They demand a sign, yet Christ’s refusal completes the divine plan (see Psalm 22:7-8 and Matthew 26:53-54).

verses.text: In the same way, the chief priests and the scribes mocked him among themselves, saying, 'He saved others; he cannot save himself.'
verses.comment: Their words recall Psalm 22:8, part of the Messianic prophecy. Jesus chooses not self-preservation but self-giving for salvation of others.

verses.text: 'Let the Christ, the King of Israel, come down now from the cross, so that we may see and believe.' Even those crucified with him reviled him.
verses.comment: They demand signs as proof, but true kingship is shown through suffering. Even the criminals mock—later one will turn to faith (Luke 23:42-43).

verses.text: At the sixth hour, darkness covered the whole land until the ninth hour.
verses.comment: Noon to 3 p.m. Darkness suggests cosmic mourning and judgment—see Amos 8:9, echoing prophetic signs.

verses.text: At the ninth hour Jesus cried with a loud voice, 'Eloi, Eloi, lama sabachthani?' which means, 'My God, my God, why have you forsaken me?'
verses.comment: Jesus prays Psalm 22:1, expressing real spiritual anguish yet trust in God. This highlights both the depth of his humanity and the mystery of his divine mission. Spiritual abandonment, not total separation, underscores unity with humanity’s suffering.

verses.text: Some of those standing by said, 'Listen, he is calling Elijah.'
verses.comment: Jewish tradition held that Elijah would return to help the righteous (Malachi 4:5); here, misunderstanding underscores their spiritual blindness.

verses.text: Someone ran, filled a sponge with sour wine, put it on a stick, and gave it to him to drink, saying, 'Wait, let us see if Elijah comes to take him down.'
verses.comment: This act fulfills Psalm 69:21. The anticipation for Elijah’s intervention points to messianic hope, but Jesus completes salvation through his own sacrifice.

verses.text: Jesus uttered a loud cry and breathed his last.
verses.comment: His final cry marks the completion of his mission—a voluntary and sovereign surrender of life (see John 10:17-18).

verses.text: And the curtain of the temple was torn in two, from top to bottom.
verses.comment: The tearing of the veil signifies open access to God’s presence, previously restricted to priests (see Hebrews 10:20). This foreshadows the new priestly order and communal access to God.

verses.text: When the centurion, who stood facing him, saw how he died, he said, 'Surely this man was the Son of God.'
verses.comment: Roman recognition of Jesus’ divinity at the cross contrasts Jewish rejection. Mark's opening claim (Mark 1:1) is confirmed here: Jesus is God’s Son—his death reveals his true identity.

verses.text: There were also women looking on from a distance. Among them were Mary Magdalene, Mary the mother of James the younger and Joses, and Salome.
verses.comment: Women disciples are faithful to the end, bearing witness to the crucifixion—underscoring the importance of sacrificial love and devoted service.

verses.text: When he was in Galilee, they followed him and ministered to him. There were also many other women who came up with him to Jerusalem.
verses.comment: ‘Ministered’ indicates diakonia—devoted service to Christ. Many witnesses will give testimony to the resurrection.

verses.text: When evening came, since it was Preparation Day, that is, the day before the Sabbath,
verses.comment: Preparation Day is Friday, when Jews prepared for rest and worship. Timing highlights fulfillment of Passover symbolism.

verses.text: Joseph of Arimathea, a respected member of the council, who was also looking for the kingdom of God, took courage and went to Pilate and asked for the body of Jesus.
verses.comment: Joseph’s boldness contrasts the secret hostility of other council members. Faithful stewardship of Jesus’ body prefigures reverence for holy things and sacred places.

verses.text: Pilate was surprised that he had already died. Summoning the centurion, he asked whether Jesus was dead.
verses.comment: Jesus’ rapid death was unusual in crucifixion—emphasizing both the completeness of his suffering and the voluntary nature of his sacrifice.

verses.text: When he learned from the centurion that he was dead, he gave the corpse to Joseph.
verses.comment: Roman confirmation of death secures the truth of Jesus’ sacrifice, which is foundational to faith and later proclamation of resurrection.

verses.text: Joseph bought a linen shroud, took him down, wrapped him in the shroud, and laid him in a tomb cut out of rock. Then he rolled a stone against the entrance of the tomb.
verses.comment: The burial fulfills Isaiah 53:9 ('with a rich man in his death'). Reverent preparation of Jesus’ body points to the importance of ritual and sacred tradition.

verses.text: Mary Magdalene and Mary the mother of Joses saw where he was laid.
verses.comment: Women witness the burial, ensuring the truth of the resurrection account. Their presence affirms the vital role of devoted witnesses in passing on the faith and safeguarding the tradition from generation to generation.
